Shields continued to appear in a string of films, including "The Blue Lagoon" (1980) and "Endless Love" (1981), both of which received significant attention for their portrayal of young love and nudity. Her provocative performances sparked controversy, with some critics labeling her as a "sex symbol" and others accusing the film industry of exploiting her as a minor.

Despite the backlash, Shields persevered and went on to study at Princeton University, where she earned a Bachelor of Arts degree in French Literature. She then transitioned to television, starring in the popular sitcom "Suddenly Susan" from 1996 to 2000.

In the 2000s, Shields expanded her creative horizons, releasing a memoir, "On Your Own," and publishing a bestselling novel, "Down Came the Rain: My Journey Through Postpartum Depression." She has also made appearances on reality TV shows, including "Dancing with the Stars" and "The View."

Throughout her illustrious career, Brooke Shields has been recognized for her dedication to mental health awareness, advocating for postpartum depression support and advocating for stronger laws protecting child performers.
